Text: It’s a sad day to lose a strong woman leader of color in the Minnesota legislature with the departure of Senate Minority Leader Melisa López Franzen.

I’m supporting all five of President Biden’s highly qualified nominees for the Federal Reserve. #FedFiveNow

Over half of Native women experience sexual violence, but Tribes can’t seek justice when these crimes are committed by non-Tribal members on Tribal lands.

I have a bill to fix that—and it’s now included in the Violence Against Women Act reauthorization. Now let’s get it passed.

Everyone who took out joint student loans with a partner still has to make their payments together—even if they’ve separated. That can mean one of them has to pay the other’s share or be unfairly penalized.

I'm on a bill led by @MarkWarner to let these loans be split up.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been an unprecedented time for all of us—but we have the tools to get through this. The vaccines are still our best shot at keeping our communities safe.
 
If you're eligible and haven't already, get boosted. We are in this together.

Happy #LunarNewYear to all who celebrate! Wishing you and your loved ones a healthy and prosperous Year of the Tiger.

Morgan Freeman says “Black history is American history.” As we mark today as the start of Black History Month, I am thinking of the immense contributions that Black Americans have made to our country. That is worth celebrating not only this month, but all year round.

We need to be honest about what’s going on here. I refuse to stand by idly in the midst of Republicans’ disgraceful treatment of Sarah Bloom Raskin, Lisa Cook, Philip Jefferson and other smart, qualified women and people of color nominated by the Biden Administration.

Republicans would have you believe differently, ignoring these nominees’ clear qualifications.
 
Instead they are again using the ugly GOP playbook that undermines women and people of color with partisan attacks that have little to do with their fitness for the job.

Sarah Bloom Raskin, Lisa Cook, and Philip Jefferson are highly qualified and dedicated public servants. Their experience, expertise, and perspective are much needed at the Federal Reserve as our nation navigates complicated economic times.
Saying a prayer for my friend @SenatorLujan as we all wish for a speedy recovery.
I'm continuing to monitor the situation on the ground in Richfield as reports come in of one death and one wounded in a school shooting. My heart goes out to the victims and their families.

Congress can make this repeal permanent. Let's finally repeal the Global Gag Rule.

But let me be clear, confirming this justice won’t fix our deeply broken Court. We need structural reform and court expansion to restore balance to the U.S. Supreme Court and ensure it protects the rights and liberties of all Americans – not just far-right special interests.

I’m looking forward to reviewing President Biden’s nomination, participating in a fair confirmation process, and filling Justice Breyer’s seat with the first Black female justice. 
 
Justice Breyer’s work has shaped our country for generations and I’m grateful for his service.

We support mining in Minnesota, but the Boundary Waters is an irreplaceable resource that we have an obligation to protect.
 
Minerals like copper and nickel are crucial to the clean energy transition, but that does not mean copper-nickel mining is appropriate everywhere.
The Biden administration has made a persuasive case that the Trump administration improperly extended Twin Metal's leases, and I support the decision to cancel them.

For more than 50 years, the Clean Air Act has reduced pollution across the US. But a case in front of the Supreme Court packed by Donald Trump could weaken those protections.
 
I'm proud to join over 190 colleagues in an amicus brief to defend clean air and fight climate change.

So let’s figure out what has 50 votes, and then let’s act without dragging this out.  Time is not our friend.

Time to focus on what's possible and deliver.

Will we get everything America needs right now? No.  
 
I’ve been in involved in complicated negotiations for a long time, and one thing I’ve learned is you have to know when to take no for an answer. And also when to hear yes and take it.

There are other parts of BBB that could have 50 votes, like child care and pre-school. 

Good, let’s do that too. I've been working on climate action and childcare in BBB since the start.

There is real space for optimism for passing good legislation, especially on climate. 

Senator Manchin has said he is ok with much of the climate parts of the bill. Good, let’s do it.

I've been in a lot of negotiations, with lots of frustration. Build Back Better is no exception.  

Here are my thoughts. [Thread]

It's Roe's 49th anniversary. And a partisan Supreme Court stacked by Donald Trump appears on the verge of ending Roe—even though the vast majority of Americans oppose this.
  
It will be incredibly hard, but we must restore balance—and the rule of law—by #ExpandingtheCourt.

It's an important change for "Impact Aid" schools so they can keep getting federal funding during the COVID pandemic.

Mel Reeves was a powerful community activist, reporter and so much more.  He was one of my favorite Minnesota reporters to talk to—smart, connected, insightful and wise. This is a terrible loss. May his memory be a blessing. https://t.co/JmWD2Et8VS
My floor speech on January 6. https://t.co/Ocd7i0bs3q

I still have faith. We can be worthy of the promise laid out in our Constitution. 

We in the Senate have the power to protect our democracy. We have no excuse not to use it.

We can’t allow it. Through the January 6 Commission and the Justice Department, we must hold accountable those responsible - including those at the top. 

And we must pass the Freedom to Vote Act, fulfilling the promise of our nation, giving the people the power to decide.

The insurrection failed, but the fight continues nationwide.

The plan is clear. Step 1) Make it harder to vote. Step 2) Give partisans the power to overturn the people’s votes.

This strategy is connected to January 6 and the path to overturning democracy if we allow it.

There’s no getting around what happened. On January 6, there was a violent attack on the United States, led by insurrectionists whose goal was to overthrow the free and fair election of President Biden. 

This happened because Donald Trump incited them to violence.
I’ve thought a lot about this day over the past year. It’s important we are clear about what happened, how it connects to what has happened since, and what needs to happen next.

On January 6, I woke up early. 

I wrote down a few thoughts and then my husband Archie popped the anxious question, “Are you going to be ok?” 

For sure I told him—the United States Capitol is one of the safest places in the country. Little did I know.

Amazing news.
 
This is how real change happens: one step at a time. https://t.co/C34eQd1AM3

Cancer is the leading cause of death among firefighters. For this Firefighter Cancer Awareness Month, thinking of the first responders and their courage as they put their lives on the line every day. 
 
I will keep pushing for first responders to get the resources they need.
